You can combine your meatballs with one of many carbolicious sides which include Mac & cheese, Parmesan-Herb fries, tater tots, Penne pasta, and many other healthier and non-healthier (read: heart attack inducing) sides.  I went there on a Wednesday afternoon for lunch and had the special for the day which was a chicken jalapeno cheddar meatball. I ordered two meatballs (you could order more than just two) with a side of Parmesan-Herb French fries. kHEjZtx2Xadsoz2kXm7yhQ.text: First of all, I've been here LOTS of times. I first came when they originally opened and I was a vegetarian. I was also fond of the taziki sauce. Both so fresh, light, and full of flavor.  And their rocket salad was always my favorite.  This was definitely a 5 star place at this point.  Then this one day, when I decided I was really to lose my vegetarian virginity, I chose the Meatball Joint to do so. The bartender was so excited for me and really helped me do it up iright. I noticed the spinach almond pesto was no longer on the menu, but there was a basil cream, and I thought that sounded fantastic.  I got 4 beef meatballs, one with basil cream, one with arrabiata, and one with mushroom gravy. They were delicious, but I was also intoxicated.  I have since gone back several times, sober, and I have to say, their sauce options are many, but they are all so thick and heavy and they just don't excite me. I've begged many times to bring the spinach almond pesto back and the manager has said he hears that multiple times a day. So why do you keep this flavorless basil cream? Basically, it's not that exciting anymore and in my opinion has gone from a fun, yummy place, to an average place that will fulfill potential future intoxicated needs. That's really not great.

eC2m-nRDNve8cstAWFpoww.text: Okay, who doesn't like meatballs? Everyone loves meatballs! What better than picking the type of meatballs and the sauce?! That's exactly what you can do here. You can pick between the type of meatballs (beef, pork, vegetarian, chicken) and the sauce (too many to list). EYNeETrP7oVJceNH84Ya5w.text: One of my favorite dinner spots in the city.   Yes - it's a meatball joint.  But don't let the simplicity of what they serve overshadow the genius of what you experience.   This menu is fully customizable. Satisfy each and every one of your taste buds as you create the meatball masterpiece of your dreams.   A creation for every craving. I'm a huge fan of the "saucy balls" entree. It comes with four huge meatballs, but you reduce it to two meat balls for a reduced fee. Enjoy it with a red sauce over pasta for a more traditional Italian fare, or pair it up with Crack Sauce over Tater tots for a more "pub-friendly" option.   Do yourself a favor and order a side of the Brussel sprouts. It might not be the healthiest Brussel sprout rendition, but it is certainly the tastiest.   Food allergy/preference friendly.

4IQ7zt7ByK0ku2YFV43oIQ.text: It would be a lie if I told you I wasn't jealous of the brilliant mind that came up with a restaurant based on jazzed-up meatballs. Although I don't think you could eat here more than twice a month without clogging your arteries completely, it's one of the tastiest meals in Pittsburgh to enjoy once in a while.  My most recent visit to Emporio was my second so far, and both times it has been incredible. Deciding what to eat is always hard here because EVERYTHING looks like it would taste wonderful. There are pork, chicken, and beef meatballs, but what really makes this place a winner are vegan and vegetarian options! Who would have guessed a meatball place has a meatless meatball? Emporio's is made of mushrooms, white beans, and cauliflower and they do have a few vegan or veg sauces and sides as well. These are on my "must try" list.  The first time I was here was during November of 2016, and at the time they were featuring their Thanksgiving meatballs with mashed potatoes, gravy, stuffing, etc. To a person that loves Thanksgiving food it was heavenly. Last week, I ordered the "Angry Birds" which are 2 chicken meatballs (massive meatballs, might I add), mac & cheese with the government cheese, "crack sauce," and blue cheese crumbles to top it all off. My boyfriend got the featured meatloaf meatballs and got them "Loaded Baked Potato" style with potatoes, tater tots, bacon bits, and lots of delicious toppings.  The singular complaint that I had about my meal was the saltiness, but when I took my leftovers home and ate them with BBQ sauce on top the next day they were phenomenal. If I could add anything at all to the menu to make this place better, it'd be some Sweet Baby Ray's. You can swap sides like pasta or potatoes for green beans or Brussels sprouts, but it's rather difficult to turn away their mac & cheese.  Overall, Emporio has a unique but simple concept, the dining area was neat and well-kept, and the staff was incredibly friendly. I'll certainly be back once I feel I've worked off my last Emporio meal, and I'll be happily awaiting trying something new from the menu until then!

N8u3JvwDrvpkF7vdghsQmg.text: My husband & I stumbled on this place looking for a place to eat downtown.  The energy was inviting when we walked through the door and we were immediately seated.  We were greeted by our server and given a full run down of the menu, since it was our first time.  I like that the menu had multiple options for the meatballs, you can choose between pork, chicken beef or veggie.  We decided to get a few apps and a drink.  The dip and bruschetta came out within 5 minutes of ordering.  Then came the crab balls & buffalo balls few minutes later. Overall, great experience-- friendly service & great food, so we would return.  Buffalo dip: Served cold.  At first I was thrown off because it was cold, but it was actually really good.  It had shrimp and crab pieces, with a nice thick texture.  They give you a good amount of dip,  but it does have a good amount of spice in it as well.  Bruschetta: 4 peices, Topped of with balsamic vinaigrette dressing, so it gave it a nice tangy touch.  The bread is toasted hard.  Crab balls:  5 balls, deep fried and seasoned well with sage.  They are crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  I'm sure they added extra spice in these as well.  The cocktail sauce balanced the flavors.  Buffalo Balls:  One word, spicy.  They served 5 balls in a bowl with bleu cheese and lettuce.  The chicken ball itself is very, very spicy (I like spicy foods, my husband doesn't).  The sauce almost has a sweet, yet spicy kick, that is baked on.  They definitely awaken your taste buds.

RT32vKtWvdMKL5uelRsncg.text: I'm gonna be honest with you here for a moment.  When I heard "meatball joint" I immediately thought I will leave here hungry.  Welp, I was proven wrong.  The menu is rather small, yet big.  I know that sounds oxymoronic, but it aptly describes this modest menu.  Small in terms that it is just the front and back of a single page.  Big in terms that the options make it an endless mix and match that will take you multiple trips to try every option it has to offer.  Quick scan of the appetizers and I already knew I was getting the Crispy Pickle Chips.  You have me already at pickle, so why roam from what I know.  Serving it with a bacon ranch dip made it just the right amount of salt flavor.  There are enough in one serving of these that sharing is a must.  Definite hit for the table.  On to the main course.  I looked over the ball selections (I know, that sounds dirty, but it is what it is, ball selection) and I decided that, no, I don't want that, so my eyes go down to the 'Bowls' section.  For my money, this was the way to go.  Think KFC, but a hell of a lot better.  I went with the Loaded Baked Potato bowl.  It is not what it sounds like.  If you were to do a quick glance at it you would think that it was a literal baked potato in a bowl with meatballs.  Wrong.  This bowl's base is a wonderfully tasting white cheddar mashed potatoes.  It is a heaping portion too.  Then they lay two good sized beef meatballs on top of this potato-y fluff.  Mouthwatering beef meatballs I might add.  Then they douse all of that with 'government cheese.'  I'm not sure what is in that, but it is exactly what you would expect.  I wanted more of that.  Next, double the potato portion here, add tater tots.  Top with crumbled bacon and scallions.  When I finished this thing, I probably looked like Beast from 'Beauty and the Beast' when he was eating his soup.  I had that bowl up to my face attempting to get every last morsel from this bowl into my mouth.  So, yeah, I got full...from a meatball place.  I was totally proven wrong, and I am fine with that.

6AAd35KRxJ6UXaBDNZ98xg.text: I'm not really sure how to take this place.  First thing is first.   I love that it's a meatball place.   And it's different. But with so many interesting other restaurant options to try, it might not be for a while.    We arrived at a good time.  Shortly before 5pm.  We were seated right away and it was nice weather so we sat at the open air seating to the outside.    The waitress was pleasant and knowledgeable. The government cheese sauce is an American cheese sauce by the way and crack sauce is reportedly a ranch and hot sauce mix.     Anyway, we ordered the uncle kunkle crazy dip which was American cheese with meat sauce and scallions.  This stuff was phenomenal.  The meat sauce was amazing. For our dinner mi amore ordered the loaded bowl with two beef meatballs, mashed potatoes, cheese sauce, tater tots, bacon, scallions.   He ordered two extra meatballs. They tasted good as well, but to me sometimes they tasted homemade sometimes frozen.   They were edible though.    Other notables were the manager walked around and talked with patrons which was nice.   The environment was endearing and comfortable as well.    All in all not blown away but it was good.

yJxW_YEJAp_sHLI7TCTSsg.text: Oh, man.  Meatballs.  Meatballs as far as the eye can see.  My sister recommended Emporio while Jules and I were on a recent trip back to Pittsburgh.  She and her husband frequented the Wexford Emporio location, but it just so happened that the downtown location was just a few blocks away from the National Aviary, which was Jules' biggest target for this trip back to da 'Burgh.  As such, a lunch date at Emporio was on the cards.  And wow.  Just wow.    Emporio was fairly busy on a Friday at lunch hour, though we were seated immediately with no fuss.  Our waiter was cordial and walked us through Emporio's numerous meatball and sauce varieties with a practiced ease.  We elected to share a basket of pepperoni fritters, while I opted for a classic beef panini (with the tomato basil cream sauce), and Jules chose the meatball poutine, made with the monthly special lamb meatballs and mushroom gravy.  My panini was done just the way it should be; crisp, pressed flat with just the right amount of char, molten cheese, and meatballs that must have been pressed by a legion of heavenly Italian grammas.  My sauce was dead on, playing second fiddle only to The Twisted Sicilian food truck, out in Indianapolis.  Plus, the panini was just the right size--filling, but not to the point where I was bursting.  The big highlight for me, though?  Those pepperoni fritters.  Damned if I'm not going to be trying to replicate that recipe, cheesy and crispy-fried, then rolled in Parmesan as they came out of the fryer.  Utterly brilliant.  Jules was brought out a bowl of poutine that I knew she'd never be able to finish and, while the meatball was delicious and the fries could have come straight out of Kennywood's Potato Patch, my suspicions were pretty well confirmed:  for a poutine, you really want a 'drippy' meat--Italian roast beef, braised short rib, or something similar.  A 'dry' protein like a meatball, even when covered with delectable gravy, just doesn't cut it.  Delicious, but not quite among the best poutines we've had.  Regardless of that, I know I'll be finding my way back to Emporio.  There's just so much goodness on that menu that I'll be hunting down a seat at lunch anytime I'm in downtown Pittsburgh.

0V4Aq1P2vyuV_OdaLqp_8A.text: I've been wanting to visit the restaurants in Sienna Mercato for quite some time now and last night I decided it was time. I thought the idea of a restaurant centered around meatballs was unique so I just had to go to Emporio. We went late at night so the place wasn't busy, but there was a decent amount of people still there. We were seated in no time. The decor of the place was very hipster and cool. All of the staff had on shirts that had some sort of "meatball humor" on them. I was very entertained.   As for food and drinks, they had a really good beer list but I may be biased because they carried one of my favorite beers (Victory Golden Monkey). The food selections were great, there's definitely something for everyone. They have a nice list of appetizers. We ended up ordering the cheesy bread and it was delicious. The marinara sauce that came with it was to die for. I also saw that they serve poutine. I didn't order it but I might have to in the future because it was hard to resist.   The meatball selection though... wow. You can choose from various kinds. They had beef, spicy pork, vegetarian, and chicken. They also had a special meatball of the month which at this time was chicken piccata. They have different ways they can be served too. You can get just meatballs by themselves, a meatball hoagie, panini, and even meatball sliders. I wasn't expecting this type of variety so it was a pleasant surprise. With your meatballs, you then can pick from an array of sauces. I ended up choosing the basil pesto cream and it was to die for with the chicken meatballs. Additionally, you can order sides to go with them. I decided to try the parmesan Brussels sprouts which were fantastic.   The only warning I have, which isn't a bad warning, is that all of the food is very rich and fills you up quickly. So, you'll have plenty to take home and eat later!

-Ox1PATDCWiMRko7JVA-3Q.text: Stopped for dinner on the way to a concert at the Benedum. The location is great, downtown in the Cultural District on Penn Ave. The restaurant is on the first floor of Sienna Mercado and has a nice open layout with a huge garage-door/window that opens right on to Penn Ave. When the weather is nice, it creates a perfect after-work/happy hour atmosphere.   But enough about restaurant design, let's talk balls. Meatballs that is. They're the focus of the restaurant and they're delicious. I ordered the Thatsa-Spicy-Meat-a-Ball! Bowl which comes with two of their spicy pork balls, cheese tortellini arrabbiata, and jalapenos tossed in their spicy sauce. Do not underestimate the spice of this one. I love spicy food and these were absolutely fantastic, don't get me wrong, but the dish is fiery! The sauce and tortellini were great, but the meatballs were truly outstanding. They were full of flavor, have a great texture, and are very large! I cut each meatball into quarters to spread the love around my bowl and because there's no way you're eating these balls in less than four bites!  I was also able to try a few bites of the classic beef meatballs and they were also delicious. Emporio packs a lot of flavor and love into each meatball, and it shows!  The only thing I didn't love was the price. My bowl was $13 and came with two meatballs, which honestly would be fine if there was a little more pasta. You can double your meatballs for $4 but $17 is steep for a pasta and meatballs, especially in Pittsburgh. Overall, still worth it, I will definitely be back. Maybe during one of their many happy-hour specials which seemed fantastic! During the week from 4-6 all drinks are half off and buffalo chicken balls are 50 cents.  TLDR: Great atmosphere, incredible meatballs, go during the happy hour!
